bibl.title: M. L. Coovert for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. Judgement
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US Circuit Courts, Western District of Washington, Seattle; Law Register Northern Division, 1890-1901, vol 1

div1.p: Filed June 22 1893 In the U.S. Circuit Court A. Reeves Ayres Clerk By R.M. Hopkins
In the Circuit Court of the United States District of Washington, Ninth Circuit, Northern Division:
Now at this time comes on this cause to be heard upon the petition of M.L. Coovert, duly filed in this Court, praying for the issuance of the writ of habeas corpus.

And upon the demurrer to said petition, duly filed by George Nerton, Sheriff of Clarke County, Washington, and upon the evidence and exhibits submitted with said petition, and upon the writ of habeas corpus issued out of this Court on the 13th day of June, 1893, and upon the return of George Nerton, Sheriff of Clarke county, State of Washington, to said writ, and the motion to discharge the petitioner and the body of M. L. Coovert, in the foregoing writ of habeas corpus mentioned, being brought before the Court at the time and the place in said writ named, and the return thereto being read; and the petitioner appearing by Mr. C. E. S. Wood, his solicitor, and moving the Court for his dicharge, and the sheriff of Clarke county, George Nerton, appearing by C. D. Bowles, his solicitor; and the Court having considered the said petition and demurrer thereto, the exhibits, the writ of habeas corpus, and the return thereto, and the motion to discharge the petitioner, and having heard the argument in the premises, and being fully advised, and it appearing to the Court that the facts and circumstances are not sufficient to justify the imprionment of the said M. L. Coovert appearing; it is hereby

Ordered, Adjudged, and Decreed, that the said law of the State of Washington, prohibiting the sale of cigarettes, and referred to in the petition, is in contravention of Article I. of Section 8 of the Constitution of the United States, and null and void, in so far as it prohibits or attempts to prohibit the selling, giving, or furnishing to any one by the importer of a box of packages of paper wrapped cigarettes each each package contains ten paper wrapped cigarettes each enclosed in paper and tin foil wrappers each bundle or package having the U. S. Internal Revenue Stamp and the number of manufacturing District and Plate which box was received by the importer packed in a wood packing case or castecailse and said carton packed with others in a common price shipping case- and that the said M. L. Coovert be by said George Nerton, Sheriff of Clarke county, aforesaid.

And it is further ordered, adjudges and decreed, that the said M. L. Coovert, petitioner, shall enter into a recognizance in the sum of two hundred and fifty ($250.00) dollars, with the clerk of this Court, with one or more sureties, for his appearance to answer the judgement of the appellate Court in the premises.

June, 1893, the same being the Judicial day of the Regular June term of said Court, Present the Honorable Cornelius H. Hanford, United States District Judge. presiding, the following proceedings were had in said cause, to wit:
